revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Missing information|description|date=July 2019}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2015}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox information appliance | title = Coleco Telstar series | image = [[image: ctelstar.jpg|description: A Coleco Telstar (first console of the Coleco Telstar series)]] | manufacturer = [[Coleco]] | type = Series of [[Dedicated console|dedicated]] [[First generation of video game consoles|first-generation]] [[home video game consoles]] | generation = [[First generation of video game consoles|First generation]] | lifespan = [[1976 in video gaming|1976]]-[[1978 in video gaming|1978]] | successor = [[ColecoVision]] | units sold = > 1 million (Coleco Telstar model only) }} The '''Coleco''' '''Telstar''' [[brand]] is a series of [[Dedicated console|dedicated]] [[First generation of video game consoles|first-generation]] [[home video game console]]s produced, released and marketed by [[Coleco]] from [[1976 in video gaming|1976]] to [[1978 in video gaming|1978]]. Starting with Coleco Telstar ''[[Pong]]'' clone based [[video game console]] on [[General Instrument]]'s [[AY-3-8500]] chip in 1976,{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=The Next Generation 1996 Lexicon A to Z: Coleco|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=15 |publisher=[[Imagine Media]]|date=March 1996|page=31}} there were 14 consoles released in the Coleco Telstar series. About one million units of the first model called Coleco Telstar were sold.{{cite book|last=Herman|first=Leonard|title=Phoenix: the fall & rise of videogames|year=1997|publisher=Rolenta Press|location=Union, NJ|isbn=0-9643848-2-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=duITAQAAIAAJ|edition=2nd|accessdate=16 February 2012|page=20|quote=Like Pong, Telstar could only play video tennis but it retailed at an inexpensive $50 that made it attractive to most families that were on a budget. Coleco managed to sell over a million units that year.}} The large product lineup and the impending fading out of the ''Pong'' machines led Coleco to face near-bankruptcy in [[1980 in video gaming|1980]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.colecovision.dk/history.htm|title=Coleco Industries. -ColecoVision History.|website=www.colecovision.dk|access-date=2019-11-05}} {{Clear}} ==Model comparison== {| border="1" class="wikitable sortable" |+ Telstar models ! width="10%" scope="col"|Console ! width="10%" scope="col"|Model and chip ! width="10%" scope="col"|Release date ! width="10%" scope="col" class="unsortable"|Integrated games ! width="30%" scope="col" class="unsortable"|Description ! width="10%" scope="col" class="unsortable"|Size (height x wide x depth) ! scope="col" class="unsortable"|Cite ! width="10%" scope="col" class="unsortable"|Picture |- ![[Coleco Telstar (console)|Coleco Telstar]] | No.6040,
[[AY-3-8500]] | 1976 | *[[ice hockey|hockey]] *[[American handball|handball]] *[[tennis]] | Two fixed [[paddle (game controller)|paddle]]s. Games are ''Pong'' variants. |Unknown | {{cite web |url=http://colecomuseum.com/colecotelstar.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-30 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004032902/http://colecomuseum.com/colecotelstar.php |archivedate=4 October 2009 |df=dmy-all }} | [[File:Ctelstar.jpg|200px]] |- ![[Coleco Telstar Classic]] | No.6045,
[[AY-3-8500]] | 1976 | *hockey *handball *tennis | Two fixed paddles. Deluxe wood case. |Unknown | {{citation needed|date=May 2015}} |No picture available |- ![[Coleco Telstar Deluxe]]
(a.k.a. "Video World Of Sports") | model number unknown, [[AY-3-8500]] |[[1977 in video gaming|1977]] | *hockey *handballs *tennis ball | Two fixed paddles. Brown stand case with wood panel. Made for Canadian market with French and English text. |Unknown | {{citation needed|date=May 2015}} |No picture available |- ![[Coleco Telstar Ranger]] | No.6046,
[[AY-3-8500]] | 1977 | *hockey *handball *tennis *[[jai alai]] *[[target shooting|target]] *[[skeet shooting|skeet]] | Black and white plastic case, includes [[Colt .45 Peacemaker|Colt 45]]-style [[light gun]] and separate paddle controllers. Four ball games, two target games. Special features of the four ball games include automatic [[Serve (tennis)|serve]] and variable paddle and speed control for three experience levels (beginner, intermediate, and professional). Uses six [[C battery|C batteries]] or an optional [[AC adapter]], light gun requires one [[nine-volt battery]]. | 4 lb.
17.5×6×8 in. | {{cite magazine |date= Winter 1978 |editor-last=Kaplan| editor-first=Deeny|title= The Video Games |magazine=[[Video (magazine)|Video]] |type=Buyer's Guide |publisher= Reese Communications|volume= 1|issue= 1|pages= 17–30|issn= 0147-8907}}{{rp|22}}
{{cite magazine |date= Winter 1979 |editor-last=Kaplan| editor-first=Deeny|title= Video Games |magazine=[[Video (magazine)|Video]] |type=Buyer's Guide |publisher= Reese Communications|volume= 2|issue= 1|pages= 33–42|issn= 0147-8907}}{{rp|35}} |No picture available |- ![[Coleco Telstar Alpha]] | No.6030,
[[AY-3-8500]] | 1977 | *hockey *handball *tennis *jai alai | Black and white plastic case, fixed paddles. The games feature an automatic serve function and variable settings for three skill levels (beginner, intermediate, and pro). Uses six C batteries. | 2.5 lb.
13.5×3.5×7.5 in. | {{rp|17}}
{{rp|34}} | [[File:Coleco Telstar Alpha.jpg|200px]] |- ![[Coleco Telstar Colormatic]] | No.6130,
[[AY-3-8500]]
[[Texas Instruments]] [[SN76499N]] (color) | 1977 | *hockey *handball *tennis *jai alai | Black and white plastic case, detached wired paddles. Color graphics - each game is a different color. The games feature an automatic serve function and variable settings for three skill levels (beginner, intermediate, and professional). Uses six C batteries. | 2.5 lb.
13×6.5×7.5 in. | {{rp|18}} | [[File:Coleco Telstar Colormatic.jpg|200px]] |- ![[Coleco Telstar Regent]] | No.6036,
[[AY-3-8500]] | 1977 | *hockey *handball *tennis *jai alai | Black and white plastic case, detached wired paddles. The games feature an automatic serve function and variable settings for three skill levels (beginner, intermediate, and professional). Uses six C batteries. | 2.5 lb.
13.5×4×8 in. | {{rp|18}} |[[File:Coleco Telstar Regent.jpg|200px]] |- ![[Coleco Telstar Sportsman]] | model number unknown, [[AY-3-8500]] | 1978 | | Black and white plastic case, detached wired paddles, and light gun. |Unknown | {{citation needed|date=May 2015}} |No picture available |- ![[Coleco Telstar Combat!]] | No.6065,
[[General Instrument]] [[AY-3-8700]] Tank chip | 1977 | *''Combat'' *''Night Battle'' *''Robot Battle'' *''Camouflage Combat'' | Four fixed joysticks (two per player). Games are variations on [[Kee Games]]' ''[[Tank (arcade game)|Tank]]''. Uses six [[C battery|C batteries]] or an optional [[AC adapter]]. | 5.5 lb.
15×8×10.5 in. | {{rp|23}}
{{rp|37}} | [[File:Telstar Combat.jpg|thumb|200px]] |- ![[Coleco Telstar Colortron]] | No.6135,
[[AY-3-8510]] | 1978 | *Tennis *Hockey *Handball *Jai-alai | In color, built in sound, fixed paddles. Games are ''Pong'' variants and feature variable settings for three skill levels (beginner, intermediate, and pro). Uses two nine-volt batteries or an optional AC adapter. | 1 lb.
2×11.25×4 in. | {{rp|34}} | [[File:Coleco-Telstar-Colortron.jpg|200px]] |- ! [[Coleco Telstar Marksman]] | No.6136,
[[AY-3-8512]] | 1978 | *Tennis *Hockey *Handball *Jai-alai *Skeet *Target | In color, larger light gun with removable stock, fixed paddles. Four ''Pong'' variants and two gun games. Uses two nine-volt batteries or an optional AC adapter. | 1 lb.
2×11.25×5 in. | {{rp|36}} | [[File:Coleco Telstar Marksman Tietokonemuseo.JPG|200px]] |- ![[Coleco Telstar Galaxy]] | model number unknown, [[AY-3-8500#AY-3-8610|AY-3-8600]] (games)
[[AY-3-8500#AY-3-8610|AY-3-8615]] (color encoder) | 1977 |Unknown | Separate [[joystick]]s and fixed paddles |Unknown | {{citation needed|date=May 2015}} |No picture available |- ![[Coleco Telstar Gemini]] | model number unknown, [[MOS Technology]] [[MPS 7600|MPS 7600-004]] | 1977 | *Four [[pinball]] games *Two light-gun games | In color, light gun, two flipper buttons on left and right sides of case, pinball launch button and field adjustment sliders on top, light gun. |Unknown | {{citation needed|date=May 2015}} |No picture available |- ![[Coleco Telstar Arcade]] | model number unknown, MOS Technology [[MPS-7600]] (each cart) | 1977 | *[[Pack-in game]] (Tennis, [[road racing]], [[Fast draw|quick draw]]) {{hidden begin|toggle=left|title=Others}} *Eight-game ball and target cartridge *Five-game pinball and shooting cartridge *Battle game cartridge *Twenty-five game driving maze cartridge *Fifteen game action cartridge (including ''Break Thru'') {{hidden end}} | Cartridge-based, triangular case includes light gun, steering wheel with gear shift, and paddles, one on each side. | 4 lb.
7.5×18×16 in. | {{rp|28}}
{{rp|37–38}} | [[File:Coleco-Telstar-Arcade-Pongside-L.jpg|200px]] |} ==References== ==External links== * [https://www.fabtintoys.com/colecovision/ The ColecoVision, with 1982 TV commercial] * [http://www.pong-story.com/coleco.htm Pong-Story: All Coleco Telstar systems, with photos] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050208141623/http://www.classicgaming.com/gamingmuseum/museum.html Telstar and other systems] * [http://thedoteaters.com/?bitstory=colecovision The Dot Eaters entry] on the history of Telstar and Coleco * [http://pongmuseum.com/history/baer-theCOLECOstory.php The COLECO Story by Ralph H. Baer] * [https://www.svg.com/94780/bizarre-console-flops-gaming-history/ Feature titled "THE MOST BIZARRE CONSOLE FLOPS IN GAMING HISTORY"] by ADAM JAMES at SVG.com {{First generation game consoles}} {{Dedicated consoles}} [[Category:Coleco consoles]] [[Category:Dedicated consoles]] [[Category:First-generation video game consoles]] [[Category:Monochrome video game consoles]] [[Category:1970s toys]] [[Category:1976 in video games]] [[Category:Products introduced in 1976]] [[Category:1978 disestablishments]] [[Category:Pong variations]] [[Category:1976 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]]
